title: Punch-Out!!
reviewText:
Punch-Out!! for the Wii is probably one of the best re-makes of a Nintendo classic I've ever come across in years.  The graphics are literally gorgeous when you compare them to other Punch-Outs for the NES and SNES, and the movesets are all very creative.  However, this game earned 4 stars instead of 5 for a few minor setbacks.

*There is only ONE new boxer (Disco Kid), not including the hidden Donkey Kong character in Last Stand Mode.  It's nice how Nintendo decided to coalesce the fighters from their previous Punch-Out games and put a slight spin on them, but seriously, if they're going to make a sequel to this, there should be completely brand-new fighters.  The fact that the fighters have different moves after you beat the game in Career Mode doesn't make up for it.  With the current game, there are 13 total fighers (14 with D.K.), but there should have been AT LEAST 6 new fighters.  They could have gotten rid of Glass Joe, Piston HondO (why the name change, I don't know), Don Flamenco, etc.  Super Macho Man and the rest of the "hardest" fighters should be permanent.  Otherwise, out with the old and in with the new.

*It's great how you can use the controller in the classic NES style.  God forbid if you use the Nunchuk and the Wiimote.  Don't even try it!  It's awful.  If you want the best boxing experience, use the Wiimote like the classic NES controller.

*About the controls themselves:  Occasionally, you won't get a response from them during the match.  When facing Mr. Sandman, for example, the character does one thing when you intended him to do something else (i.e. dodging his delayed overhand smash and winding up not hitting him in time when you pressed the correct button).

*The sound bites and music are amazing.  Great tunes and awesome voices.  However, this can be totally taken in a racist direction.  You have Bald Bull screaming, "Achmed!!  Allah!!" (Muslim terrorist); Great Tiger with his Taliban-esque vocabulary; Piston Hondo with his Jap stuff; etc.

*There were also some technical errors I discovered.  During the Mr. Sandman match (you can see how much I love this guy), Doc Louis says in between rounds, "Wake Mr. Sandman up!! The fans wants a new champ!!"  That's grammatically incorrect, and the designers should've noticed this error.  Also, the ages given for the boxers DO NOT correlate with their physical appearance.  Super Macho Man is 27 years old????  He's got white hair and looks like he's in his 50s.  Come on, now.

Overall, the game was a very entertaining experience.  I thoroughly enjoyed it.

4 Stars out of 5.  The breakdown is as follows (on a letter grading scale):
Graphics:  A
Sound:  A
Gameplay: B+
Controls:  B-
Replay Value:  A

title: Tomb Raider: Underworld
reviewText:
I have played two Tomb Raider games so far:  Underworld and Anniversary.  This review comes after playing both games, and I thought Underworld was an amazing game after playing it first, but when I played Anniversary, Underworld's faults became readily apparent.

For one thing, there are quite a few glitches in this game.  Please be sure to save at every two checkpoints or so!!  I've had my Wii freeze on me completely after some of the cutscenes, which really made me frustrated to the point where I didn't want to play the game ever again.  However, I did continue on because the story is fascinating.  Both the storyline and the gorgeous graphics are the highest points in the game.  The architectural and visual detail put into this game are truly sights to behold.

Those good points mentioned above are what gives this game 3 stars.  Besides the glitches, the controls are also fumbly, in particular, the camera angles.  Getting Lara to face the precise direction while performing jumps is quite agonizing, to say the least.  In summary, this game is great to rent, but I'd only suggest buying it if it's $5 in the bargain bin at Walmart.

title: Uncharted: Drake's Fortune - Playstation 3
reviewText:
This game definitely belongs in your PS3 library.  In fact, it should be a requirement that you buy this immediately with your PS3 system.  Uncharted:  Drake's Fortune is a SPECTACULAR game, full of puzzles, non-stop action, and gorgeously breathtaking cinematics.

Now what I'm going to say next isn't necessarily a bad thing, and it doesn't affect my 5-star review of the game, but the premise of Uncharted really isn't new at all.  In fact, this game borrows heavily (and at certain points, STEALS) from the Tomb Raider series A LOT.  Just take a look at the way Nate jumps on ledges, wall runs on vines, etc.  That's a bad thing when it comes to creativity/originality, but hey, Tomb Raider was awesome, and it's great to see another well-produced game along those same lines.

As for the storyline of the game, elements of it were heavily borrowed from the movie "Romancing the Stone" with Michael Douglas and Kathleen Turner (Nate taking Douglas' role, and the female journalist taking Turner's).  The similarities are remarkable here!  So obviously, the developers of the game had both Tomb Raider and "Romancing the Stone" in mind when they developed Uncharted.  Uncharted 2 is also out right now, so maybe that's like "Jewel of the Nile"?  I have yet to get the sequel (which I will definitely do), and then I'll see where the inspiration for that one came from.

Amazing, isn't it?  I love how I can get to the heart of what's behind games such as these.

title: God of War: Collection - Playstation 3
reviewText:
God of War: Collection is definitely one of the finest compilation games to ever hit the PS3.  These two games together on a single Blu-Ray disc at such a reasonable price are fantastic.  Great storyline revolving around Greek mythology, tons of blood and gore, excellent cinematics, decent control scheme, and lots of merciless killing.  Definitely my type of game (and not for the faint of heart or little kids)!  Not playing continuously, both games took me between 10 and 15 hours total to complete, so they're very epic in scope.  The puzzle portions of the games seemed a bit lackluster and could be more challenging, but overall, everything else trumps that particular aspect.  As of this writing, God of War 3 has just been released, and I'm psyched to get it in the mail soon (review of that one is pending).

On a side note, Greek mythology is a fantastic genre to make video games with, but after the God of War trilogy, there should not be any more video games revolving around that.  GoW has officially set the standard and raised the bar to which no other video game can compete, and it's best to leave the Greek mythos alone after this series is complete.  Mythology itself, however, should continue to be explored and developed in the video game industry.  Perhaps we'll see Roman, Celtic, or Hindu mythology next???  Would be an awesome idea (hint hint to any video game developers reading this!!!).  In fact, I'd LOVE to see a video game featuring a heavily Christian/religious element with saints and such.  Would make a mind-blowing concept, don't you think?

In any event, definitely pick up GoW: Collection when you get the chance.  These two games are considered to be staples for Playstation owners, and that's the truth.

title: Assassin's Creed - Playstation 3
reviewText:
Overall, I did enjoy Assassin's Creed for the PS3:  excellent storyline with great kill animations and very detailed cutscenes with plenty of audio.  The cutscenes may be too much for some people, but I happen to enjoy games featuring those things.

I give AC 3 stars mostly due to the fact that there is no trophy support at all, the game is extremely repetitive which could get boring after a while (same types of missions and basic linearity), and the controls are a bit clunky (particularly with the camera angles when running/climbing walls...Altair would jump in a direction you didn't intend him to jump in).  Without the trophy support, there was really no reason at all for me to complete every single mission, view point, etc.  Just completing the minimum 3 investigations required to gain access to the assassination memories is good enough.  I'm hoping that Sony will release trophy support as a free DLC in the future, but I'm not betting on it since they haven't done so already after 3 years.

I will definitely purchase AC 2 sometime in the future, since all reviews are saying that it beats the original game by a long shot.  I'd still highly suggest that you play this game through first just because it's the first title in a supposed trilogy.

title: Dante's Inferno Divine Edition - Playstation 3
reviewText:
Let me just get this out of the way first:  Dante's Inferno is most definitely a rip-off of the God of War gameplay.  That is completely undebateable and unquestionable.  Now that's not necessarily a bad thing.  God of War did set a defining standard for many future games with regard to combat systems and control schemes.  And to be honest, it WORKS for Dante's Inferno, and Electronic Arts perfected it.  So if you have played God of War, Dante's Inferno should be very easy to pick up and play right out of the box (and if you never played GoW, please do so immediately!).

Just the whole concept of Dante's Inferno is terrific . . . traveling through the 9 Circles of Hell to find your long-lost love is one heck of a storyline to drive the rest of the game.  The graphics are fantastic, the GoW style is beautiful (with the additions of equipping relics and upgrading tons of stuff via Holy/Unholy Paths), and everything is just laid out wonderfully.  The enemy characters are also very well-designed, from the various demons and unbaptized babies to Lucifer Himself.  The only gripe I have is that the boss battles should have been a little more involved and not just about button mashing.  Same could be said for the puzzle component, but those points are just very minor compared to the game overall.

Also, I instinctively knew that this game was going to be the first of three more to come (basing things off the Divine Comedy itself).  The "To Be Continued..." epigram at the end of the game hints to that, so we should expect Purgatorio and Paradiso to come out over the next few years.  If EA does that, we have a fine contender on our hands to compete with the God of War Trilogy!  In fact, Dante's Inferno is much better than both God of War and GoW 2.  This game is a must-buy.  Highly recommended!!!!

title: God of War III - Playstation 3
reviewText:
Part Three of the Trilogy is officially one of the worst games I have ever played.  It is clear that this game went straight to the developers' heads, much like their well-beloved main character, Kratos.

So where do I begin?  Well, let me just say that the game started off brilliantly.  The battle with Poseidon is by far my favorite boss battle in the entire God of War series.  The graphics are really top-notch, except I did detect a tiny slow-down in the frame rate during the first section of the game.  I guess they were just trying to push the PS3's limits a little too far.

I really can't say much for the game play, since it's just more of the same from the previous two GoW titles.  I absolutely loved the increased amount of gore and bloody finishers for the bosses.  On a side note, I really don't like the voice acting on Kratos' character.  It sounds like a black guy is speaking the voice of somebody who isn't black.  Very strange and odd if you ask me.

But besides all that, what I severely find fault with is the storyline.  Plain and simple, Kratos is seeking revenge on all the gods.  That's it.  Kill Zeus is his goal, and that's what he does.  Nothing wrong with that, since it seems to fit the overall plot of the entire trilogy.  However, the game really went downhill as soon as Pandora entered into the equation.  What an ANNOYING brat!  Why didn't Kratos kill her as well?  He turned his back on the Titans, mutilated the gods...why not also kill a helpless "child"?

Where things really got annoying was with the final boss battle with Zeus, particularly when you have to face him and his clones inside Gaia.  I'm very happy to admit that I never finished this game out of extreme rage and frustration during that part of the battle.  After the twenty-fifth try (YES, twenty-fifth!), I just said "to **** with this game!" and let it go.  I deleted the saved games from my system and everything.  Never in my life have I found ANY boss battle so tedious (and this was on NORMAL difficulty!).  The developers clearly committed some grave error during the battle with Zeus.  Twenty-five times, and STILL you can't beat him?  Is this some sick joke to actually turn the player himself INTO Kratos???  Perhaps so, but regardless, I got sick of all the BUTTON-MASHING during that part of the battle, since that's all you could do.

To sum everything up, God of War III felt like a drug that puts you into severe withdrawal:  a consistent high for quite some time, and then a sudden depression sets in.  This game should definitely not get any Game of the Year awards whatsoever.  If it does, I'd be very surprised.

UPDATE:  I have beaten this game since this review was originally published, and I'm giving it an extra two stars (so three total, instead of the original one star I gave it).  This game is still by no means a 5-star title.

title: Batman: Arkham Asylum - Playstation 3
reviewText:
When Joker says that line over the loudspeaker outside Arkham Asylum, I almost died laughing.  "Hello kiddies!  It's your Uncle J!"  You just have to love The Joker, and he's reason enough for you to buy this game.

Batman: Arkham Asylum is a watershed moment for the Dark Knight himself.  It's truly a fantastic game with a superb storyline.  The graphics and cinematics are splendidly done.  The FreeFlow combat system is pretty ingenious, albeit a bit too easy to use.  Batman also has a vast plethora of gadgets available at your disposal to kick some serious thug *ss.

What prevented me from giving Arkham Asylum a stellar 5-star review was the fact that not enough villains were included in the game.  I would've loved to see the Penguin, Catwoman, Mr. Freeze, and the Riddler in the flesh (or the pixels, in this case).  I also felt that there should have been more boss fights.  The Titan henchmen were sort of lame, and you just fight Bane, Poison Ivy, and Joker as the three main villains.  I don't count Zsasz and Harley Quinn, since their demise was pathetic.

I also found the Challenge Maps to be quite repetitive and optional at best.  For those of you who are all into getting every single trophy in the game, you may want to take a look at the Challenge Maps, but they're not necessary.  Finding every Riddler Trophy and riddle in the game is also purely an option, but they add a little spice to the fiesta.

Is the game a must-buy for your PS3?  YES, but I'd suggest only buying it if you're into Batman to begin with.

title: Castlevania
reviewText:
Alright, the very first thing I'm going to say is this:  those of you who came into this game with a jaded mindset, thinking that it was going to be like all the other Castlevania titles, should really be ashamed of yourselves for giving this game low marks.  Your bad reviews for this game should never be taken into consideration because you let your biased opinions get in the way of your judgment.  Lords of Shadow is NOT like any other Castlevania game, and it must be judged on its own.

Secondly, those of you who give this game sub-par reviews for its lack of originality and "derivative gameplay" should also be chastised severely.  Yes, it borrows from previous titles (God of War, Shadow of the Colossus, etc.), but SO WHAT?  It WORKS.  It's a great game with an awesome storyline...enough said.  The graphics are beautiful, the cutscenes are gorgeous, and you really get the most bang for your buck.  LoS clocks in at between 15 and 20 hours worth of gameplay, and it's enough to actually keep you interested.  Until the day comes when a "new" style of gameplay is introduced, we just have to deal with this type of action-combat-hack n slash format.  So just deal with it, learn to love it, and shut up!

One last comment that I'd like to make about Lords of Shadow refers to the voice acting.  All of the major actors play great roles and read their lines well...BUT, I'm a little annoyed at Patrick Stewart's performance.  His presence in this game was actually the number one reason that caused me to purchase LoS...me being a huge Star Trek: The Next Generation fan and all.  But I must say that Patrick should have read his lines with a little more emotional "oomph" during the opening scroll scenes for the chapters. During those introductory scenes, it just feels as if he falls flat when saying certain lines, with a couple of long and drawn out sections.

Also, my favorite word that I LOVE hearing him say is "artifacts."  Not ONCE did he mention this word in the game!  In the scroll scenes, the word "relic(s)" pops up like 10 or 15 times.  WHY couldn't they have replaced that word with "artifact(s)"?  I was so annoyed by that that I had to write to Patrick Stewart myself and also send a comment about it to Hideo Kojima Productions.  The only time I felt that Patrick really hit his stride was during the very last chapter of the game.  Only then did I hear any REAL performance from him.

So there you have it.  Should you buy it or rent it?  Buy it!  The game has plenty of replay value since you have to complete all the trials if you want to collect some silver trophies.  You will also have to replay some of the levels if you want to find any weapons upgrades.  All in all, the game is great.

title: Assassin's Creed II - Greatest Hits edition - Playstation 3
reviewText:
Assassin's Creed 2 (AC 2) is such a tremendous improvement over its predecessor in many areas:  graphics, layout of the levels (gorgeous graphics and painstaking attention to detail), the addition of more weapons and gadgets, and some fun side quests.

However, they still didn't get something right:  the jumping and wall climbing!!!  Why is it that when you want Ezio to jump in an intended direction, he jumps in a totally different direction?  Performing quick button presses when you have to jump or wall climb can get very annoying.  Also, there are quite a few glitches in the game.  When you viciously slaughter enemies, their body parts may get stuck in the floor.  I also encountered a glitch where I performed a jump off a building, landed in between a tree and the side of the wall, and got stuck in the wall.  I had to reset my PS3 after that happened.

Another thing:  it is very well-known that Leonard da Vinci was a homosexual.  In Dan Brown's book, "The Da Vinci Code," he mentions that da Vinci was a flamboyant homosexual.  Other sources also seem to confirm Leonardo's flamboyance.  If he was so flamboyantly gay, why is he portrayed in such a masculine fashion in AC 2?  If the designers of this game REALLY wanted to be historically accurate, they should have altered Leonardo's behavior to more accurately reflect his natural "flair" for the aesthetic arts.  And who knows...a plot twist of Ezio and Leonardo getting it on maybe would have made the game a LOT more interesting!!  But I digress...

Overall, 4 stars due to the glitching, jumping/wall-climbing nuisances, and historical inaccuracy.

title: Grand Theft Auto IV - PlayStation 3
reviewText:
I can't believe how many hours of my life I literally wasted playing this game.  60% of the game is based on completing the main storyline missions, and I got up to 51%.  The mission "Paper Trail" is THE most ridiculous mission ever in GTA history.  In that mission, you are supposed to take a helicopter and shoot down a target helicopter miles away with Little Jacob in the passenger seat.

I can't tell you how many times I tried doing this mission, to the point where I'm about to write an official letter to Rockstar Games.  GTA MUST have a difficulty setting adjustment!!!!  No excuses.  How can you make a game with ridiculously frustrating missions towards the end of the main storyline without any difficulty adjustment whatsoever?  This is mindless and idiotic, to say the very least.

I've had a lot of difficulty with some previous missions, and luckily, I got through those, but "Paper Trail" really puts the icing on the cake.  The other 40% of the game consists of side missions, which are worthless, in my opinion.  That's an even bigger waste of time!  And if you're one of those trophy-hunting nuts who needs to have every trophy in this game, then you've got no life at all.  Save your efforts on another game, not this one.

As a result of all this, I'm happy to say that GTA 4 is now collecting dust on my shelf.  Early on in the game, I was heavily thinking about purchasing Episodes from Liberty City, but that's definitely not happening.  It gives me great pleasure that Rockstar Games will not be making $20 to $30 off me!

I'm very glad that I got this game for free through Amazon promotional credits I've saved up, because I tell ya....I would not have spent any sort of currency on this title!!!  I haven't played Red Dead Redemption yet (which is on my shelf in the shrink wrap), but if it gives me the same amount of frustration, I will NEVER purchase a game featuring the "golden R" ever again.

Darksiders is a third-person, single player action/adventure game inspired by the characters, themes and mythology of the apocalypse and the battle of Armageddon described by the Book of Revelation. Once the unstoppable and just wielder of divine retribution, War is now reduced in stature and cast out amongst the ruined lands of the Earth that he himself devastated. All that remains is the search for the truth behind his betrayal and the survival of its consequences.

The Story
Deceived by the forces of evil into prematurely bringing about the end of the world, War - the first Horseman of the Apocalypse - stands accused of breaking the sacred law by inciting a war between heaven and hell. Dishonored and stripped of his powers, War must return to Earth to search for the truth and punish those responsible. But there is no clear definition of good and evil in this tale. Hunted by a vengeful group of angels, War must take on the forces of Hell, forge uneasy alliances with the very demons he hunts, and journey across the ravaged remains of the Earth on his quest for vindication. But the answers he seeks will reveal a deep conspiracy in which War will find, and have to resign himself to the reality that although once the hand of God, he is just a pawn in the eternal battle between heaven and hell.

Gameplay
A mix of exploration and fast-paced action gameplay, Darksiders is based on nonlinear play situations. That means that as War slowly regains his previous powers of destruction and carnage in order to continue his search for the origins and reasons for his betrayal, players will be able to backtrack to areas and scenarios that they may have left unexplored upon first discovery. Almost all areas of the game can be explored and some of the things players will find as they do so are treasure chests, health chests, and bonus life points, etc. The ability to go back and explore areas is important, especially as the game progresses and War finds himself up against enemies whose defeat require special skills and/or weaponry.

As for combat gameplay, Darksiders features a variety of weapons--including blades and firearms--that can be used in combo moves or in single strikes. Some of these can be charged up for quick, but devastating attacks on enemies and all can be arranged on your controller\'s D-pad for easy and preferred access. Additional gameplay elements include the ability/necessity to fight from the back of your mount, Ruin, and the collection of the souls in the form of glowing orbs that fall to the ground as enemies are dispatched. The latter can be used to level up War with new items and abilities.

Varied Characters and Environments
Although players take on the imposing role or War, Darksiders also contains a wide variety of equally intriguing and sometimes frightening characters. These include: an assortment of vengeful angels; demons, such as "the Jailer" whose body is made up of the remains of countless cadavers; a bestiary of wicked and vile creatures created to bolster the armies of hell on Earth; and Ruin, the trusty steed of War. Gameplay environments players will experience are equally varied, and include areas both underground and on the surface, that call to mind both familiar, if ruined modern urban environments, as well as ones seemingly pulled from the nightmarish scenes of the biblical apocalypse.

title: Demon's Souls
reviewText:
Ok, so this review is a little incomplete since I didn't finish the game yet, but whatever.  It's a great dungeon-crawling, boss-slaying RPG with decently good graphics.  Yes, it's hard...yes, it's difficult.  My main build is the Royalty class Assassin build.  I just use magic all of the time, and it's a breeze.

So far, I beat levels 1-1, 1-2, 2-1, 3-1, 4-1, and 5-1.  When I got to 2-2 (Flamelurker level), I stopped playing.  I came very close to beating him, then I died and got sent back to the beginning of the level (which is what usually happens when you die anywhere in the level anyway).  No big deal, so I started over.  The thing is that I just got bored of that level, and for some reason, I kept dying trying to get through it again.  No clue why because I breezed through it the first time around.  The level has plenty of platform jumping and falling if you choose to go that route.  I tried that a few times, and I kept on dying.  A major disappointment with the game is that you can't control your direction of falling.  Once you fall, you just go down.  To me, that's a major weakness in this game.

Other than that, it's pretty solid.  And here's a tip:  if you know you're going to die or immediately when your health is completely depleted, just press the PS button and quit the game.  When you load your file up again, you'll respawn at the point before you died.  Doing that has been a lifesaver for me, and if I never knew that, I probably would've gotten very frustrated with the game and quit it a long time ago haha.

So yeah, after losing my patience with 2-2, I just put the game on my shelf for the time being.  I just don't have the patience anymore for it, especially since I have 11 unopened games that I still have to play.  Rest assured though that I will return to Demon's Souls in the future (next year, most likely).

title: Red Dead Redemption - Playstation 3
reviewText:
Simply put, Red Dead Redemption should be in every PS3 gamer's library.  It has Rockstar's signature sandbox formula a la Grand Theft Auto, yes, but it's set in the Wild West!  RDR is definitely a unique game in its own right for that reason.  The cutscenes are plentiful and beautifully rendered.  The storyline is decently good, too, with a large cast of characters.  There's also PLENTY to do in this game, from main story missions to side objectives to hunting & gathering.

I decided to give it 4 stars because the controls at times could be a little clunky....I thought that activating Dead Eye could be a little less troublesome.  When you have to switch weapons on horseback and then go into Dead Eye, that can pose a problem and it cost me a few deaths in the process.  Also, I didn't like the fact that if you're out hunting & gathering, every single animal/herb collection is completely lost if you die in between main missions.  They could have at least put in an auto-save feature after each collection, like they did with Demon's Souls.  So the control scheme and the loss of items definitely warranted a one-star deduction from this game.

Keep in mind that it will take you at least a month to really complete this game.  I personally did not finish the game (i.e. achieve 100% completion), but I feel qualified to post a review for it based on the fact that I completed the entire Main Story missions.  All Amazon reviewers for this game should have at least accomplished that before posting their reviews.  I'm going to put this game on my shelf and come back to it later after I beat 10+ other games I have left to play.  When the time comes, I'll go for 100% completion and also buy the Undead Nightmare pack.

I can't comment on the multiplayer portion of the game because I never tried it.  I'm more of a single player type of guy than multiplayer, but that's just my own personal thing.

This game knocks 'em red dead with 4 stars.

title: Mayflash Wii/PS3 VGA HDTV AV Cable
reviewText:
Alright, so I bought this cable to hook up my Wii to my PC monitor.  I have a 2011 27-inch Acer 3D HDMI 1080p monitor.  I followed the instructions and successfully "calibrated" the cable on my family's downstairs TV first.  Then I hooked up my Wii via the cable to my computer monitor.  Please note that you need another VGA to VGA cable in order to hook it up to your monitor.  Luckily, I had one of those on hand...

So after setting it up, both audio and visual worked, and the colors looked fantastic.  However, after a few minutes of playing, the screen would suddenly fade to black for 2 seconds, and it kept on doing that every few minutes.  It's VERY annoying!!  This seems to be a common complaint for a lot of consumers, and after scouring the Internet for answers, I could not find any.

I know the problem can't be my monitor because it's top-of-the-line.  My Wii settings were all set perfectly at 480p, widescreen or standard (doesn't matter, I got the same 2-second black screen).  SO WHAT'S THE PROBLEM??

My guess is that the cable is faulty or built incorrectly.  Maybe that extra VGA to VGA cable you need is screwing up the transmission somehow?  The connection is a little loose there, too..like you can't screw in the male VGA into the female VGA tightly enough since there are screws on both ends.  The problem definitely is not with my monitor at all, that's a fact.  I'm not sure what alternative I have left...maybe purchasing a VGA to HDMI cable (although I read that's impossible without also buying a converter)?  I don't know, but if I don't get an email response and a definitive answer within a week from Sewell Direct (where I bought it from), I'm returning it for a full and unquestionable refund.

I'm going to be moving next year, and I really don't want to have to purchase a TV just to play Wii through the component cables (I don't need cable television since I have Netflix on my PS3 through my monitor).  So when that time comes, this thing HAS TO work on my PC monitor; otherwise, I won't be able to play Wii at all.

This review will be updated again.  If I get an answer that allows me to stop the black screen fades, then I may add a star or two.  If I don't get an answer or the problem continues, I'm downgrading this review to one star, getting my refund, and filing a complaint with the Better Business Bureau against Sewell Direct for selling faulty equipment to the American consumer and charging him/her for it.

UPDATE:  I notified the manufacturer about the black screen issue, and they told me that it's due to the Wii overheating and that Nintendo has done nothing to address this problem.  I'm not sure if that's just a blame-game type of maneuver, but I wound up emailing Nintendo, and they told me to call them.  I don't know why they couldn't resolve this through e-mail and tell me what to do.  The black screen only lasts for 2 seconds every 4 minutes or so...not that big of a deal really.  I'll live with it.  My 2-star review still stands as is.

title: Super Mario Galaxy 2
reviewText:
I'm a lifelong Mario gamer, and I must say that this game is NOT for first-time Mario players.  I would never recommend this game to a Mario newbie.  The game is visually amazing, yes, but when you get to World 5, things get pretty insane...enough to throw your controller at the screen and give up after 50 stars (which is exactly and proudly what I did).

You see, the thing is that once you get to World 5, you need 55 stars to get to World 6.  At most, you can only get about 51 stars from doing only the main star missions in all the galaxies up to that point.  You then have to get stars by doing the Prankster comets and various timed race missions (which are HORRIBLE...I've always hated those timed races).  That should not have to be the case at all.  In previous Mario games utilizing the star system, you were able to advance only by doing the main star missions.  Why isn't this the case here?

Because of that fact, I give this game 2 stars overall and it's the worst Mario game to date.  It's also a practically complete repeat of the first Super Mario Galaxy game, so it's lacking in originality severely.  Also, most of those side missions actually require a second person to play co-op.  Absolutely sucks...The end of Mario games as single player endeavors is over, and that's really sad.

title: Resistance: Fall of Man - Playstation 3
reviewText:
Resistance: Fall of Man is one of the first (if not, THE first) game to debut with the original launch of the Playstation 3 system, and by golly, it's a great one!  It's a great first person shooter with an excellent storyline akin to "War of the Worlds".

The game is divided up into 30 levels of non-stop, alien-mutilating action with cutscenes at the completion of each level.  The A.I. in this game is truly amazing.  The Chimera are somewhat difficult to target, and they sneak right up on you!  You really need to actually focus your shots every time.  The theme song to this game is also great to listen to.  Armin Shimerman is one of the voice actors in this game.  I'm sure you remember him if you're a Trekkie.  He played Quark in Star Trek DS9.

Now I took off one star from the game because I felt that there weren't enough checkpoints adequately placed within the levels.  There's nothing more frustrating than dying in a level and then have to go alllll the way back to the beginning because there wasn't a checkpoint where it should be.  Also, I was disappointed that this game doesn't have a trophy system.  There are "skill points" to accumulate, but I don't see how they would benefit unless you're into the multiplayer portion of this game (which I didn't bother to play).  Those skill points could have easily been translated into trophies, and that's what Sony should have done.

Other than that, this is a solid 4-star game at the very least, and it should be a staple in your PS3 library.

title: Sonic Generations - Xbox 360
reviewText:
Sonic Generations is the finest Sonic game in years.  It's such a return to form for the franchise, and it's great to see a Sonic game with both 2D and 3D elements.  All the levels are cleverly designed, and you can tell a lot of work went into them.  At times, I felt like some of the levels were just way too fast-paced, but hey, this IS Sonic the Hedgehog we're talking about!

The time travel element to the storyline is pretty good, too.  You can get through the main story in a good day or so, but the collectible items and achievements really add a nice touch to it all.  The only minor issue I had with the game was the final boss.  I found that level to be a little odd, and it took me a few tries to find out exactly how to beat it.  All you have to do is keep holding down the X button to boost and dodge all the debris.  When I found that out, this level became the easiest boss stage in the game.

The challenge gates are a very nice addition as well, and they keep you busy even after you beat the game.  I didn't collect all the items and pass all the challenges, though, but if you're an achievement getter, then you should definitely attempt the extra levels.

All in all, this is a very fine game, and a work of art as far as Sonic is concerned.  5 stars

title: Batman: Arkham City for Playstation 3
reviewText:
Batman: Arkham City (AC) is a worthy sequel to its predecessor, Arkham Asylum.  In this game, you explore a city rather than a prison colony, and the controls are exactly the same.  The FreeFlow combat system is also similar, with the inclusion of new gadgets and double counters.

As far as the storyline goes, I found Arkham Asylum's story to be better on the whole.  In AC, I did not like Hugo Strange's role in the plot, as well as his collaboration with Ra's al-Ghul.  Joker is the main villain once again, and that's definitely not a bad thing.  I just felt that all the other villains detracted from the focus on Joker (disconnected plot lines were apparent).

Speaking of the villains, I'm glad that the designers decided to incorporate plenty of new bad guys in this game; however, I felt that a few of them weren't designed like they should be.  For example, the Penguin has this weird, cockneyed English accent when he really should be speaking with a nasal bird-like sound.  Also, his hands were not webbed at all.  For Mr. Freeze, he never spoke in a Germanic accent at all, although his robotic suit voice was pretty cool.

The Riddler was also never seen as a physical entity in the game, other than in projection form.  Supposedly, he appears in the flesh at the very end of a side mission when you collect all 400 (yes, FOUR HUNDRED) riddler achievements.  That's not good enough for me, though.  No way did I go around collecting all the riddler trophies and solving all the riddles.

Speaking of collectibles, there's a TON of stuff to find in this game, and I certainly didn't bother with collecting everything.  All I did was beat Batman and Catwoman's main storyline and called it a day.  All the other Riddler trophies, Riddler's Revenge, and side missions I found to be extraneous.  The other DLC (Robin & Nightwing) are completely useless and a waste of money, unless you're a trophy collector.

When you beat the main storyline, that's enough to have beaten the game entirely (in my opinion).  When I beat 100% of the main storyline, my total progress was only 36% (according to the game).  According to me, I was at 100%.  My other statistics at time of completion included:  16% side missions, 25% upgrades & collectibles, 13% Catwoman's collectibles, and no Riddler Challenges.  I didn't even bother with New Game + mode either.  In fact, playing the whole game on Normal difficulty was extremely hard.  The fights are very tough on that mode!

The Catwoman DLC package wasn't bad either.  Her main storyline revolved around her stolen goods with Two-Face.  As far as she is concerned, she wears these pinkish sunglasses on the top of her head, and I wished that she'd actually wear them on her face while you were playing.  You only see her put them on for 2 seconds at the very end of the game.  Such a cheap blow...  Also, her detective radar mode was very poorly designed.  You can't tell who's armed and who's not, which led to plenty of needless deaths.

Speaking of deaths, a major character dies at the end of the game.  If said character is indeed dead, how are they going to make another Batman game?  They'll have to either bring the character back, or never make another Batman game again.  And IF they do make another one, I hope it doesn't fall under the Call of Duty syndrome (i.e. same old story again).

Overall, I give Batman: Arkham City four stars (really 3.5, but I gave it the benefit of the doubt).  It's a 2011 Game of the Year nominee, but it never reached that iconic status this time around.
